lines.text: It's a funny thing, Joe, how you always manage to drop in just when we're startin' to eat.
Thanks, pop. I'll have a cup of coffee with you. Might go for a block of wheatcakes, too.
Sorry, Joe, I didn't have time to make wheatcakes this morning.
Oh, that's all right. I'll eat anything you got.
And that's no idle boast.
I've gotta' start to work. I won't have *time* to do these dishes.
Never mind 'em, Colleen. I'll stack 'em in the sink, and they'll be ready for you to wash when you come home.
This sure is an elegant chop suey parlor. It don't look on the level to me.

[presents a vintage French wine]
Chateau Huit, 1923.
Now listen, buddy. I'm a guy you can't push around. I pay for the best, so I want the best. Now you take that 1923 stuff back, and bring me this year's model!
As monsieur wishes.
[makes a long face and takes the bottle away]
You sure do things up right. You're a regular man-about-town.
"Man-about-town"? Hey listen, honey, you ain't seen nothin' yet. I'm the original boulevardier from the Bronx. Ha ha!

[Ames has a black eye]
What you need is some beefsteak for that eye.
Oh, that's just propaganda put out by the meat packers so they can sell more beef.
Come on, you're not gonna' tell a Reilly how to cure a black eye.

[puts a slab of raw beefsteak on his black eye]
How does it feel?
Feels like you got the whole cow on me!

[aboard an ocean liner]
Ah, the sparkling salt air. Nothing like an ocean voyage - nothing, nothing!

[she's seasick]
No, except ptomaine poisoning. I'm never going to Europe again until they build a bridge from New York.
Well, smart-aleck, aren't you going to do something? What about "London, Paris, Vienna in the spring..."?
Ah, this is bad, this is serious...
I didn't have to come here to find that out.

[with a pondering expression]
I got it! Somethin's gotta' be done. Something brilliant, a stroke of genius!
What, for instance?
I'll tell ya' after.
After what?
After I think about it myself.
